fields.title: Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency
fields.description: Provides assistance for the following mortgage and housing-related expenses to help prevent mortgage delinquencies, default, foreclosure, and displacement. The maximum amount of assistance for any homeowner under the PAHAF is $30,000 or up to 24 months of assistance.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 8:00pm
Saturday, 8:00am to 5:00pm

fields.title: ACTION-Housing
fields.description: Helps homeowners to avoid foreclosure through counseling, working with lenders, and applying to available programs; can also connect to additional social, health, and financial resources as well as educational and employment opportunities.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 4:00pm
fields.address: 611 William Penn Place Suite 800 Pittsburgh, PA 15219

fields.title: Advantage Credit Counseling Service
fields.description: Offers pre-purchase counseling counseling sessions to assist prospective buyers to understand the mortgage process; foreclosure prevention counseling helps current homeowners to avoid foreclosure when possible. Also provides information about reverse mortgages in special sessions.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8:00am to 8:00pm
Friday, 8:00am to 5:00pm

fields.title: Advantage Credit Counseling Services of NEPA
fields.description:
Remote sessions take about 90 minutes to complete while the traditional face-to-face sessions can take over 2-3 hours.
Counselors are certified by PHFA and NeighborWorks. Participants needs to have a Smartphone, tablet, laptop, or desktop computer and a device that has a web camera so that the counselor can clearly see you during the session.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Mon - Fri, 8:30am to4:30pm, Counseling appointments flexible hours as scheduled, Saturday hrs available.

fields.title: BASE, Inc
fields.description:
Provides housing counseling including:
- pre-purchase counseling
- default and delinquency counseling
- foreclosure prevention counseling
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 9:00am to 5:00pm

fields.title: Berks Community Action Program, Inc.
fields.description:
**NOTES**
Office currently operating on an Appointment Only basis.

A state program to help those who have worked hard to purchase their homes to keep them during short periods of financial turmoil. The Homeowners Emergency Mortgage Assistance Program provides homeowners who have received an Act 91 notice a chance to apply for a loan to pay their mortgage until they are able to regain their financial footing. Counselors review each individual situation and prepare the necessary paperwork to be mailed to the state for a decision.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 4:30pm

fields.title: Blair County Community Action Agency
fields.description: Information and access to resources for people who are finding it difficult to make the mortgage payments on their homes and are at risk for foreclosure.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Hours vary.

fields.title: Blueprints
fields.description: Provides foreclosure prevention services for homeowners in danger of losing their homes.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 9:00am to 4:30pm
fields.address: 150 West Beau Street Suite 106 Washington, PA 15301

fields.title: Center for Family Services
fields.description:
Assists in negotiations with lender for a Loan Modification or a Forbearance Plan, budget counseling, referrals to other services, and will help explore additional refinancing options.

People with an Act 91 Notice should contact immediately, there is a limited window to apply for assistance.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 4:00pm

fields.title: City of Philadelphia
fields.description: Provides free housing counseling and free legal advice to give homeowners a way to negotiate with their mortgage lenders. Housing counselors can also assist with property tax questions and appeals.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 9:00am to 5:00pm

fields.title: Clarifi
fields.description: Clarifi works with struggling homeowners in all stages from those who are current but facing potential future delinquency to those whose homes are scheduled for sheriff's sale.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 6:00pm

fields.title: Community Action
fields.description: Provides assistance with housing emergencies such as foreclosure, eviction, and essential utility termination (heat, electric, water/sewage), as well as emergency shelter and assistance to locate permanent housing; assistance with budgeting, and addressing other issues affecting the household through referrals to community resources.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Hours may vary

fields.title: Community Action Committee of the Lehigh Valley
fields.description:
- Homeowners' Emergency Mortgage Assistance Program: Provide assistance to homeowners at risk of losing their home to sheriff’s sale
- Home Ownership Counseling Program: Provides seminars for first time homebuyers. Certificate presented at completion to help acquire lower interest loans. Call for schedule: held 7 times per year. Offered at various locations in both counties.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 4:00pm

fields.title: Brookline Teen Outreach Center

fields.title: Carbon and Schuylkill SHINE After-School Program
fields.description: Afterschool program for children K – 12 at school centers throughout Carbon and Schuylkill Counties. Students are referred primarily for academic purposes. Educational programs, including homework assistance and STEAM-focused projects, are taught and a hot meal is served. Also offers summer programs.

Office: 8:00am to 5:30pm

fields.title: Central Pennsylvania Food Bank
fields.description: Provides access to nutritious food through programs such as School Pantry, Kids Cafe, Backpack, and Summer Meals. Coordinates programs in conjunction with local school districts and municipalities.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Thursday, 8:00am to 4:30pm; Friday, 8:00am to 3:00pm

fields.title: Children and Adults Developmental Agency (CADA) Programs
fields.description:
Provides after-school programming for children, in a safe, nurturing, drug-free environment conducive to learning and emotional balance.

Various programs offer tutoring, mentoring, cultural activities, STEM skill-building, safety education, nutritional support, and more. Visit the website for more information on the available programs.

Hours: Monday through Friday, School Dismissal to 6:00pm
Office Hours: Monday through Friday, 10:00am to 6:00pm

fields.title: City of Philadelphia - Office of Children and Families

fields.hours_of_operation:

fields.title: Family Services of Montgomery County

fields.title: Four Mile Church
fields.description: Provides after school programming, peer counseling, and tutoring. Program also includes dinner, and activities such as healthy cooking class, art, music, mechanics, crafts, games, lessons.

fields.title: Hanover Area Council of Churches
fields.description: Provides a weekend backpack food program. NOTE: Children receive a backpack on Fridays filled with 7 meals that can be easily prepared.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Call for information

fields.title: Helping Harvest
fields.description: Distributes fresh fruits and veggies at dismissal time at area elementary schools
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 4:30pm

fields.title: Neighborhood Resilience Project
fields.description: Provides weekend meals for children/youth in need. Each participant receives six (6) meals each weekend.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Office Hours: Monday through Friday, 9:30am to 4:30pm.

fields.title: NEPA Youth Shelter
fields.description:
After school teen drop in center for high school students.
Provides essentials such as food, clothing, and bathrooms, as well as services such as educational support, counseling, family reunification, and/or preparation for independent living. We Provides snacks, dinner and groceries to take home are available.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Center is open Monday through Friday from 3:00pm to 6:00pm, September through June.

fields.title: Nutritional Development Services
fields.description: The Archdiocese of Philadelphia recognizes that student wellness, proper nutrition, and regular physical activity are related to a student's physical well-being, growth, development, and readiness to learn. It also recognizes that schools can provide an environment in which students can learn about and participate in positive dietary and lifestyle practices. The Archdiocesan School Wellness Policy addresses the nutrient content of food at school, nutrition education, physical activity, and other environmental factors that promote a healthy school environment.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Call for information

fields.title: Second Avenue United Methodist Church
fields.description: The ROCK (Reaching Out to Community Kids) - This after school program meets each Wednesday night during the school year (unless school is cancelled that day). This program is open to any children Pre-K through 12th Grade, and provides children with a home-cooked meal, lessons, gym time, arts/crafts and more. Children need to be registered by a parent or guardian on their first visit.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Program Hours: Wednesday, 4:30pm to 7:00pm

fields.title: Chester County Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP)
fields.description: Distributes funds provided by the American Recovery Act to assist eligible renters facing court-ordered eviction, a utility shutoff, or a need for a security deposit to secure permanent affordable housing.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Resource Navigators are available for intake 24/7.

fields.title: Dollar Energy Fund
fields.description:
Assists utility customers who meet income and payment eligibility guidelines with a $100 to $500 grant applied directly to their utility bill. Program Dates:

October 1 to November 29: open for services that are off or threat of termination only.
December 2 to March 31: open for services that are off only.
February 3 to February 28: open for services that are off or in threat of termination.

To apply for Dollar Energy funds, the account holder must live in the home. The grant covers residential, single home or apartment service. "Cooking only", commercial, industrial or apartments with shared utility service are not eligible. Applicants can only receive one grant per utility, per program year (October 1st through September 28).
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday through Friday, 8:30am to 8:00pm

fields.title: Indiana County Community Action Program
fields.description:
The Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP) provides assistance to households that have experienced financial hardship and may be at risk of homelessness due to Covid-19. ERAP provides tenant households assistance with rental and utility costs to include arrearages and other related housing expenses.

Details about the requirements and a list of Frequently Asked Questions are available on the United States Department of the Treasury website.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: COMPASS application is available online 24/7.

fields.title: Mercer County Housing Authority
fields.description: Provides rent and utility funds for those whose housing is in jeopardy due to income loss due to COVID-19.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Monday, Tuesday, Thursday: 8:00am to 4:00pm; Wednesday, Friday: 11:00am to 7:00pm; Saturday: 10:00am to 2:00pm
fields.address: 700 Martin Luther King Boulevard Farrell, PA 16121

fields.title: PASW Counties Using COMPASS for Emergency Rental Assistance Program
fields.description:
The Emergency Rental Assistance Program (ERAP) provides assistance to households that have experienced financial hardship and may be at risk of homelessness due to Covid-19. ERAP provides tenant households assistance with rental and utility costs to include arrearages and other related housing expenses.

Details about the requirements and a list of Frequently Asked Questions are available on the United States Department of the Treasury website.

fields.title: Lubbock County General Assistance
fields.description:
Description
Provides assistance to residents with a partial payment towards the current month's rent. This agency does not assist with deposits or pay any amount in arrears.

Utility assistance must be for the current month. This agency does not assist with arrears, re-connection fees or deposits. The utility services must be in service, and in the name of someone living in the household. Does not assist with telephone bills.

Provides cremation assistance to anyone who is a Lubbock County resident or has expired in Lubbock County.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Mon - Fri 8:00 am - 12:00 pm, 1:00 pm - 5:00 pm

fields.title: Hockley County Public Assistance
fields.description:
Description
Provides utility assistance for gas, electric, butane. Only usage amounts are considered for payment and the amount may only be for the current one month past due amount up to $75. Also provides rental assistance for the current month only and the maximum payable amount is $150.

Provides access to Pauper Burial applications and services, policy is, cremation only.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Mon - Fri 9:00 am - 5:00 pm

MUST BE A STUDENT OF AMARILLO COLLEGE AND QUALIFY UNDER THEIR REQUIREMENTS.

Must be an Amarillo College Student and fall withing the center's qualifications.

M - F 8:00 AM - 5:00 PM

fields.title: Don & Sybil Harrington Cancer Center

The Circle of Friends is a volunteer non-profit support organization that provides limited emergency financial assistance to current cancer patients receiving treatment at the Harrington Cancer Center.

Limited funds are available for expenses such as travel, lodging, rent or mortgage, utilities, prescribed nutritional supplements, take-home prescriptions, breast prostheses and other special needs. Assistance is provided on a short-term basis and requests are considered on a case-by-case basis.

Mon-Fri, 8:00am-5:00pm
fields.address: 500 South Taylor, Suite 603 Unit 223 Amarillo, TX 79101

One-time auto insurance, auto payment, auto repairs, bus passes, and/or
Child care assistance; and/or
One-time utility payments; and/or
Security deposit for new living quarters
NOTE:  This is only for eligible VETERANS WITH DOCUMENTED COMBAT SERVICE and no dishonorable discharge and their spouses. Please do not refer anyone else as they will not get assistance. Combat service means that the veteran served at least one day by land, sea or air in an imminent danger pay zone. Combat service should be noted on the DD-214. These zones can include World War I, World War II, Korea, Vietnam, Persian Gulf, Afghanistan or Iraq (OIF/OEF).
 
Please note: Payment (s) are paid directly to the Vendor NOT the Beneficiary.

fields.title: Bell County
fields.description:
Description
Not accepting applications or appointments at this time. 

Bell County has partnered with Hill Country Community Action Association to assist eligible households that are unable to pay rent and utilities due to Covid-19 pandemic.

Eligibility requirements:
Households must have income at or below 80% of the Area Median Income (AMI) as defined by HUD.
Household Size- 1 with Gross Annual Income of $35,800
Household Size- 2 with Gross Annual Income of $40,900
Household Size- 3 with Gross Annual Income of $46,000
Household Size- 4 with Gross Annual Income of $51,100
Household Size- 5 with Gross Annual Income of $55,200
Household Size- 6 with Gross Annual Income of $59,300
Household Size- 7 with Gross Annual Income of $63,400
Household Size- 8 with Gross Annual Income of $67,500
And
One or more of the tenant household members have:
Qualified for unemployment benefits OR
Attest in writing that due to or during the pandemic they experienced a reduction in household income, incurred significant costs or experienced financial hardship
And
Households must also demonstrate they are:
At risk of homelessness or housing instability OR
Live in unsafe  or unhealthy housing conditions
Must be primary residence located in Bell County
Any unpaid rent or utilities can only go back to March 13, 2020
Application process:
Visit website for application and required documents/Bell County ERAP Checklist
Documents can be uploaded to the kiosk on the website, faxed or dropped off at the nearest center:
Temple HELP Center 604 N 3rd St Temple, TX 76501
Main Phone 254-870-9986
Pick up application Mon- Thursday 9:30am-2pm
Call to schedule an appointment to drop off an application
Killeen HELP Center 204 Priest Dr Killeen, TX 76541
Main Phone 254-870-9986
Pick up application Mon - Thurs 9:00am-3:00pm
Call to schedule appointment to drop off completed application
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
To drop off an application, call to schedule an appointment.

fields.title: St. Austin Catholic Church
fields.description:
Description
Offers limited financial assistance via a weekly drawing for either rent or ONE utility bill (including electric, water, OR gas bill). 

Applicants MUST reside in the City of Austin to receive rent assistance; or must have an Austin Energy/City of Austin utility bill to receive utility assistance. 

Eligible individuals MUST email or text gethelp@staustin.org to be added to the drawing. The email or text MUST include your phone number,  a picture of your photo ID, and an image of either ONE utility bill OR images of your lease. The bill or lease must be in your name.

The church will randomly draw names from all eligible email submissions. If your name is drawn, you will receive a phone call on Thursday morning from a "blocked call" number and you must answer to receive assistance. All help will be given remotely.

Applicants do NOT need to email or text every week. All names will stay in the drawing for 1 month (or earlier if chosen). 
Assistance is extremely limited. Applicants who are not selected in the drawing will not be notified. 

St. Austin Catholic Church is not able to offer the following: mortgage assistance, birth certificates, photo ID cards, eye exams and glasses, work boots, Food Handler License assistance, nor clothing vouchers. 
Does not assist with rent or utility deposits. Does not assist with hotel or motel payments. Rental payments cannot be made to individuals, even those with a lease.

fields.title: Travis County Health and Human Services
fields.description:
Description
Applications are closed, this record remains active for informational purposes only. 

Provides rental assistance and mortgage assistance to income-eligible Travis County tenants residents who are unable to pay rent due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Families can apply at the county website or request a paper application from a county community center. If applications are approved, payments will be made directly to the landlord or mortgage company.

The payments will help with up to three months' rent or mortgage, but assistance will not exceed what is owed within 30 days. Monthly payment will also not exceed the average city rents as of Jan 1, 2022, which are as follows:
Efficiency: $1,334
One bedroom: $1,500
Two bedrooms: $1,900
Three bedrooms: $2,395
Four or more bedrooms: $2,795
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Applications are closed, this record remains active for informational purposes only.
Online applications accepted 24 hour a days, 7 days a week from March 1, 2022 until funds run out; it is recommended to apply as soon as possible

Financial Help - Provides financial assistance fo qualified individuals and families for rent, mortgage, utilities, medical services, and other services.
Clothing Assistance - Based on availability, provides clothes and basic household item to qualified individuals or families at no cost from the retail store Random Hangers and Warehouse.

To receive financial assistance, bill must be past due and the applicant's name must be listed on the account. Cannot assist with current bills. 
Depending on current funding and client's need, it is possible that clients may be eligible for more than one type of assistance. However, the assistance is only available one time. Assistance is not available on an ongoing basis. 

All assistance is paid directly to the provider (e.g. the utility company).

fields.title: Longview Community Ministries (LCM), Inc.
fields.description:
Description
Provides Financial Assistance for:
Utility assistance - limited to a maximum amount of the last $100 of an electric and last $50 of gas or water bill. The bill must indicate the name of the person requesting aid, who in turn must not have received assistance within the last 2 years. Referral to other local agencies for services and referral to area educational opportunities.  Clients receiving utility assistance (unless never assisted before) will be required to take Money Management class within 3 months of assistance. Failure to take class results in no further financial assistance (other than food).
Emergency rental assistance: limited and available to families on a one time only basis who can provide proof of a Longview address and meet certain criteria. Families must have signed separate documentation (LCM will provide the correct form) indicating evidence of paying full market rent. If the family has not received emergency rental assistance within the last two years, they may be eligible for the Incremental Housing Assistance Program (IHAP). IHAP requires clients to attend one class per month for the duration of 4 months to qualify for increments of $200; $100, $100 and $100 per month toward rent.

**Note: Anyone living the zip code service area can visit any emergency service location for basic needs. Must visit central location in order to access resources for medical assistance, which include: emergency dental care (tooth extractions); eye exams and eyeglasses; and assistance with some medical prescriptions on case-by-case basis.



Inquiries for financial assistance (rent/utilities) are still being received via phone and clients must call for an appointment. Standard zip code requirement remains. During COVID-19, clients will be asked to email or fax supports documentation related to their crises. Interviews will be scheduled the next day and conducted over the phone.

fields.title: Harris County Community Services Department
fields.description:
Description
Helps eligible Harris County tenants stay in their home and provides landlords an alternative to eviction. The TEDP may provide up to six months of rental assistance for eligible tenants who are behind on their rent due to the COVID-19 pandemic and have been sued for eviction.
Both the tenant and the landlord must agree to participate and meet the requirements in the chart below.
Assistance can be used to pay the full contracted rent that is past due (up to five months), and the remainder may be used to pay for subsequent months of assistance (up to a total of six months). 
The TEDP uses a special court process that allows courts to put eviction lawsuits on hold and divert them to the TEDP.
Diverted cases will be dismissed and made confidential from public disclosure.

Counseling services, funeral expenses, lost wages, assistance with medical bills, reimbursement of expenses as a result of a crime, such as doctor visits and mileage, among others.
Crime Victim Compensation (CVC): http://www.laredopd.com/crime-victims-coordinator/

fields.title: Hope Alliance
fields.description:
Description
Hope Alliance offers offers two different type of housing/shelter options:

Housing program -  offers assistance with securing longer-term housing, beyond the limited stay available at our emergency shelter. To be considered for housing support, you must go through a screening and approval process and an appropriate apartment unit must be available. Our housing options are designed to assist families who are struggling with credit or rental histories as a result of their abusive relationship. The supportive housing program is available to current clients of Hope Alliance only. Sliding scale and reduced rent programs are available. Clients who participate must also be participating in case management services with a Hope Alliance advocate.

Hope Alliance's Emergency shelter -  can house up to 35 adults and children who stay for an average of around 30 days. Within 24 hours of entering the shelter, survivors are assigned a case manager who will meet with them weekly. At that first meeting, the resident and case manager will work collaboratively to develop a list of line items and goals that that individual resident hopes to achieve while in shelter. These goals can be both short and long term goals. The residents also can meet with a legal advocate and a crisis counselor, if needed. Residents have access to a clothing closet, basic toiletries (shampoos, soap, lotions, razors, hair products, etc.), and a plethora of food items for meals and snacks. We encourage the future residents to bring only a reasonable amount of personal items with them. The shelter is an undisclosed location, and privacy and confidentiality and of course safety is this team's top priority. Unfortunately, the shelter typically has a waiting list of survivors needing shelter.

For more information on our emergency shelter, please visit our website or call us at 512-255-1212.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
24 hours a day, 7 days a week

Offers a database with over 5,000 agencies and resources in communities all across the country. Helps concerned friends, family, co-workers and others seeking information and guidance on how to help someone they know. Educates communities all over through events, campaigns, and partnerships with companies.

COVID-19 Update: Upon arrival to Harvest Time Church, follow the directions

food will be placed in your vehicle.
There will not be access to a public restroom.

In partnership with the North Texas Food Bank, a mobile fresh produce
pantry is offered every Friday to low income Grayson County residents
at Harvest Time Assembly of God, 222 S Heritage Pkwy from
8:00 am - 11:00 am.  

The 2nd Friday of each month, supplemental commodity boxes will be 
available to income eligible seniors, age 60 and over. Interested seniors
must register ahead of time in order to receive a box on the distribution
day. The box contains a variety of food including: milk, cheese, canned
meats, peanut butter, canned fruits and vegetables, rice, pasta, fruit juice
cereal and instant non-fat milk.

Provides a monthly box of food to low-income older adults to improve the health, nutrition, and well-being of their lives.  

Box may contain: 
Protein (e.g., non-perishable chicken, salmon, tuna chili, stew)
Non-perishable vegetables/fruit
Bag of dried beans or jar of peanut butter
Pasta
Two-pound block of cheese
Hot or cold cereal
Bottled fruit juice
2% milk

fields.title: NICA (Northside Inter-Community Agency)
fields.description:
Description
Provides services to Older Adults 60+ with a supplemental food program every 2nd and 3rd Saturday for the elderly and people with disabilities. Provides case management, home repair assistance, and financial assistance when available. All services under this program include;

Older Adults Assistance: NICA will consider any reasonable financial request from a Older Adults such as Medical supplies, Medication, Fans, Space Heater, Clothing, Furniture, and Hygiene Items. 

Older Adults Supplemental Groceries: While NICA provides food for all qualifying individuals through its food pantry, Older Adults taking advantage of the Good Works Program receive monthly supplemental groceries that last for one or two weeks. For Older Adults who are able to visit NICA, food is picked up from the food pantry, but NICA also offers home-delivered groceries for Older Adults with transportation and mobility issues.

God’s Hands Home Repair Program: Offers Older Adults financial assistance, or the services of a handyman to perform much-needed home repairs.

Social Services: NICA offers comprehensive case management, along with application assistance,  home visits, and monthly reassurance phone calls, to reach out to Older Adults who are in need.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Client Service Hours: Tues – Fri 9:00 am - 3:30 pm
Supplemental Food: 2nd and 3rd Sat of the month 9:15 am - 11:45 am
fields.address: 1600 Circle Park Blvd Fort Worth, TX 76164

fields.title: Foster Angels
fields.description:
Description
Provides funding for basic needs for foster children.
May offer assistance with the following: 
Meals and grocery assistance
New school clothes, school uniforms, shoes, undergarments, diapers, and personal hygiene items
Furniture needs such as beds, mattresses, bedding, cribs, and household items
Funding for transportation needs such as car seats, strollers, bus passes, gas cards, and car assistance.
Assistance with educational needs such as tutoring, testing, school supplies, backpacks, tablets, and driver's education classes.
Funding for therapeutic and medical needs such as therapy/counseling, eye exams/glasses, medical exams, specialized medical equipment and supplies
Recreation activities such as camps, team sports, music/art/dance lessons, and after school activities and clubs
Special occasions such as adoptions, holidays, birthdays, prom, graduation, and other celebrations.

fields.description:
Description
Offers supplemental food and nutrition program for pregnant or breast-feeding women, infants, and children up to the age of five (5) years.

Applicants who have a nutritional needs receive individual and group education. The WIC Program provides breast-feeding education and support to participating breast-feeding moms and pregnant women.

EBT Benefits are redeemable for nutritional foods, such as milk, cheese, infant formula, infant cereal, fruits/vegetables, whole grains and baby foods.

fields.title: Women, Infant, and Children (WIC) for Hays, Caldwell, Comal, and Guadalupe Counties
fields.description:
Description
Provides the WIC (Women, Infants, and Children) nutrition program. 

Offers nutrition education, breastfeeding education and support, and referrals to other health and human services.
Provides food benefits via the WIC EBT card to help purchase nutritional food and baby formula.

May provide breast pumps to WIC participants if needed, as determined by WIC clinic staff.
WIC refers individuals to their health plans first for breast pumps, however, WIC still provides pumps to participants who:
 • Are unable to get pumps from their health plans, or who are uninsured
 • Are unable to get pumps from their health plans in a timely manner* 
 • Have received a pump from their health plan that is not appropriate for their needs

* It may take a while to get a pump through a health plan, so if there is any sort of waiting period for getting a pump via a health plan, individuals should go to WIC. WIC can loan a pump until a health plan pump arrives.

Program is administered by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA).
fields.hours_of_operation:
ProgramAtSite Hours:
First Wed of each month; Second and Fourth Thurs of each month; 9:00 am to 3:00 pm

Distributes H-E-B food vouchers once a month. Food vouchers may be used for food only; vouchers cannot be used for tobacco or alcohol. 

May provide clothing vouchers to be used at Second Chance Emporium in La Grange.

May provide household good vouchers for victims of household fires or floods to be used at Second Chance Emporium.

Does not provide rent or utility assistance.

A.M.E.N. is a volunteer group of local churches and is supported by sales from the Second Chance Emporium, and from individual donations.

Serves as a Central Texas Food Bank partner. All clients are entitled to basic rights set forth by the Food Bank, including: to be treated with dignity and respect, to receive food at no cost without showing any documentation, to not be required to participate in a religious event, and to not be discriminated against.

fields.title: Schulenburg Area Food Pantry
fields.description:
Description
Provides a self-choice food pantry where clients may select their own food. 

May offer canned vegetables, produce, frozen or canned meat, peanut butter, milk/dairy, and bread depending on availability.
Provides household products (e.g. cleaning supplies), when available.

May distribute vouchers to be used for groceries at Arlan's Food Market. Clients must receive assistance from food pantry to request an Arlan's vouchers; vouchers are not given as a standalone service.

Also offers the For the Children program to provide an extra bag of child-friendly food to families at their monthly food pantry visit. Gives a “birthday bag” for each school-aged child during the month of their birthday to help the household provide a family birthday party for the child.
 
Also offers the Schulenburg Pantry Inviting Community Elderly (SPICE) program to provide additional nutritional food to seniors, ages 70 years and older, at their monthly food pantry visit. Gives seniors a gift card for one free buffet meal at Oakridge Restaurant in their birthday month. 

Serves as a Central Texas Food Bank partner. All clients are entitled to basic rights set forth by the Food Bank, including: to be treated with dignity and respect, to receive food at no cost without showing any documentation, to not be required to participate in a religious event, and to not be discriminated against.

fields.title: Street Youth Ministry
fields.description:
Description
Operates a drop-in center for youth who are homeless, traveling, or at risk of becoming homeless.

May provide the following:
a hot or cold meal and snacks
clothing
toiletries
pet supplies
first aid items
cold weather supplies when weather appropriate, such as blankets, coats
one sleeping bag every 12 months and after first visit (beginning on Nov. 1 for first cold snap through March)
backpacks every 4 months and after first visit
Provides the following services to clients in addition to the above:
online peer support groups, Bible study, women’s group, prayer group, devotional group, game night, talent night, and movie night on zoom and Facebook live.
one-on-one counseling onsite outside, with masks and social distancing, or via Facebook messenger with one of our “at home” staff members.
earned laundry program by attending online groups
access to volunteer tasks that earn “points” redeemed for bus passes, guitar strings, headsets, and other items
printing by email - one page free and additional pages are a nickel each
mail and package delivery to our address
Access to the following services for clients with a lease who were previously homeless clients of SYMin or enrolled in another program to reduce homelessness:
small household items (kitchen, décor, etc.)
food pantry bags for clients with housing on a lease
Does not provide overnight shelter, nor overnight services of any kind. 
Does not arrange transportation, fund housing, pay bills, nor provide cash. May refer eligible clients to programs that can offer this assistance.

Provides volunteer opportunities.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Drop-in center: Mon - Fri 12:00 pm - 5:00 pm
Central Library: Tues and Thurs 1:00 pm - 3:00 pm
Helpline: Mon - Fri 9:00 am - 5:00 pm

Breakfast: Mon - Fri 9:00 am - 9:30 am

Phone use: Mon, Thurs and Fri 10:00 am - 12:30 pm
Computer use: Mon  10:00 am - 12:30 pm and Thurs Fri 9:00 am - 12:30 pm; 20 minute limit; only work related time allowed; printing available (10 sheet limit)

7-day bus passes: for up to 60 people on Wed starting at 8:15 am. Long distance bus passes are on a case-by case basis
30-day bus passes; one available per month

SNAP Assistance: Fri begins at 9:30 am; not always available
Case management services: Ask staff for an application
Call 512-610-3500, Mon - Fri 10:00 am - 1:00 pm for additional information. Leave a voicemail with name and phone number for a return call.
 
Masks are required to be worn when requesting services at the center.

Description
Provides interview suits and career development services for women who are seeking employment and referred for program services by approved Partner agencies. Female veterans, wives of veterans, and wives of active military members may self-refer. Assists transgender clients.
  
Women-identifying people are helped by an Image Consultant in selecting two interview outfits, shoes, handbag, jewelry, undergarments and cosmetics. Clients also receive literature on interview etiquette and are scheduled with a Career Consultant in the Career Center.
Clients may receive additional professional clothing after procuring the job and are invited to join the Dress for Success Professional Women's Group.

Accepts donations of clean ready-to-wear business suits and blouses on hangers, handbags, scarves, gently worn shoes, jewelry and unopened cosmetics and toiletries.

Description
Serves people who for one reason or another cannot get help from other programs or agencies. We can offer help with paying utilities, minor home repair, including ramps, ID’s, birth certificates, other documentation to work toward self-sufficiency or clothing to go to work. We have a warehouse ministry to serve others with used furniture, some new furniture and gently used household items.

We do not have a rental assistance program, however, we have some funding from the community for rental assistance if you have been affected by Covid-19 and a referral from your employer is required.

A home visit is always scheduled as we don’t want to make a determination just by paperwork. We serve only Nacogdoches County. We make referrals to other programs that can help you if we cannot.

fields.title: Gill Childrens Services
fields.description:
Description
Provides one-time, emergency assistance for children's unmet needs. Provides financial assistance with, though not limited to, the following: birth certificates, diapers, medical, dental, vision care, mental health expenses, medical equipment, prescriptions, tuition, glasses/contact lenses, local transit passes, and emergency child care expenses. Payment for services goes directly to service provider (doctor, hospital, dentist, etc.), not to the child or family. Family must apply before the service is rendered; Gill does not provide reimbursements. Gill does not provide housing, food, utilities or clothing assistance. 

**All resources must be exhausted before applying at Gill Children's Services. Before applying, the client needs to answer "YES" to all three questions below to be considered,
Is my child 0-18 years old?
Does my child live in Tarrant County?
Have I called 211 to see if other nonprofits can help me?

Every person participating in the program is issued a non-transferable ID punch card which entitles them to one bag of food and hygiene necessities a month, such as adult diapers, waterproof pads, vitamins and reading glasses;
Various times a year, on the third Friday of the month they are welcome to come back to a monthly “Senior Citizens Health Fair.”
During the fair many agencies serving the elderly gather to provide glucose check, blood pressure measurement, etc.
Open to anyone age 60 years and older with a photo ID is eligible for the Silver Star Ministry Program.
For more information contact the church at 956-712-0655, if you know of any senior citizen in need, please reach out to New Vision Community Church.

fields.title: Front Steps
fields.description:
Description
Operates a day resource center for adults experiencing homelessness, offering the following: 
Use of client telephone to make local and long distance calls. Client phones are intended for outbound calls only, and do not accept incoming calls.
  Community board for message posting
  Mailing address for clients to use to receive personal mail. Clients must show their ServicePoint ID card (given by Front Steps) to receive mail.
  Employer phone line with a designated contact number that clients may share with employers and potential employers. Messages left at this number will be posted to the message board. The employer phone line is intended for job-related matters only. 
  Personal hygiene supplies
  Showers with soap and shampoo provided. Towels are provided.
  Restrooms
  Laundry facilities with detergent provided. Allows clients to clean 1 load of laundry every 5 days. 
  Lockers - Distributed via a lottery system on the 15th of each month, or the following Mon if the 15th falls on Sat or Sun. Clients may keep their locker indefinitely, but must re-register each month between the 1st - 10th.
  Document Bank – A secure filing cabinet to store client's documents (e.g. driver's license, birth certificate)
  Computer Lab with desktop computers and Internet access. The first two computers near the volunteer desk are reserved for job searching and resume writing. The remaining computers can be used for recreational purposes. 
  Administers ID cards to clients. These "Servicepoint ID cards" include the client's photo and name, and may include date of birth with client's consent. It's possible some social service agencies may accept this card in lieu of a state-issued identification card to receive services, but that decision is up to each individual agency. These ID cards are not formal identifications documents and may not be used in place of government-issued ID cards (i.e. cannot be used at a bank to cash a check). 
  Printed referrals to other community resources, including those offering financial assistance. Staff can assist clients in mapping transportation to other agencies. Provides written information on how to obtain an ID, but cannot assist clients in applying for or paying for ID replacement.
  Some options may be available for individuals to stay indoors at resource center during the day, when daytime temperatures are freezing or extremely hot.
  Hosts monthly town hall meetings for clients to express concerns, suggestions, and comments; and for staff to discuss program changes and issues.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Program Hours:
Day Resource Center : Mon - Sun 6:30 am - 5:00 pm pm; closed for cleaning 10:45 am - 12:00 pm

Showers: Tues 7:00 am - 2:30 pm; Wed - Mon 7:00 am - 3:30 pm

fields.title: I Support the Girls

Distributes donated essential items, including bras, underwear, toiletries, and menstrual hygiene products for women and transgender teens and adults experiencing homelessness, impoverishment, domestic violence, or distress through several programs:

ASH (Aid, Safety, Hygiene) Kits: customizable care packages that can be requested by individuals who qualify for each program.
D.A.S.H. Kits: Survivors of domestic violence who are fleeing an abusive situation
Flash Kits: People going through perimenopause or menopause who are experiencing homelessness or could not otherwise afford products for symptom relief.
Slash Kits: For all who identify as transgender or otherwise, and cannot afford or safely purchase gender affirming undergarments and toiletries.
Disaster Relief Program: sends aid to areas affected by flooding, fires, and other disasters that require sudden evacuation.
Force for Change: advocacy and special requests from partners to creates long term change for unique populations.
Breast cancer survivors
Individuals formerly incarcerated
Immigrants and refugees
Migrant farm workers
Native Americans
Transgender teens and adults
Veterans
Youth

For a list of FAQs, visit this link.

Donations can be mailed via USPS only to a nearby location, or:
I Support the Girls
Attn: Dana Marlowe

Wheaton, Maryland 20915

If shipping will be via UPS or FedEx you can mail products to:

fields.title: PPL Corporation
fields.description:
Regional electric utility provider.
Provides specialized customer assistance programs such as:
* Operation HELP: Pays energy bills for eligible customers (funds can be used to help pay for any fuel source, including oil, coal, kerosene, electric, etc.) low income customers. OpHELP is administered by CAP.
* OnTrack: A special payment plan that offers reduced monthly payments, protection from shutoffs and debt forgiveness. For residential customers who are struggling to pay their bills. OnTrack is administered by CAP.
* Customer Assistance & Referral Evaluation Service (CARES): A personalized service for customers experiencing bill payment problems due to temporary hardship.
* Rebates and Savings Programs - : Offers programs to help customers save energy.
Call 866-306-2479
* Refrigerator and Freezer Recycling
* Appliance Rebates
* Home energy surveys/energy analysis

Optional billing programs include:
* Budget billing which allows customers to pay about the same monthly amount all year long
* Automatic Bill Payment Plan offers customers the option of automatic deduction of the bill from a checking or savings account on their monthly due date.
* Payment-Date Extension Plan allows customer to extend the due date of the electric bill to coincide with their monthly pension/social security check.
* Double Notice Protection Plan enables customers to arrange for an individual or social service agency to receive a copy of all overdue or termination notices to alleviate problems.
PPL is regulated by the Public Utility Commission.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Office: call center hours Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 5:00 pm; Emergency service available 24/7

fields.title: PPL Electric Utilities - Lehigh Region
fields.description:
Electric Utility Provider.

Customer Assistance Programs include:
- WRAP (Winter Relief Assistance Program): Free weatherization and energy education program. Services include installation of energy saving light; changing/cleaning heating/cooling filters; replacement of waterbed coils with a foam mattress; refrigerator replacement; water heating measures (for electric water heating customers only); attic, duct, floor and wall insulation; blower door testing for air leakage (drafts); door and window weather-stripping; "whole house" foaming and caulking and door sweeps and thresholds. Eligibility criteria include household income, age, and be an individual metered PPL customer living in a primary residence. If renting, landlord permission required. Home can not have received WRAP services for at least seven years.

- CARES: A program for customers who cannot pay the full amount of their electric bills because of temporary personal or family hardships. Previously good-paying customers having a temporary hardship situation, recent loss of job or major reduction in household income, abandoned spouse or low-income elderly, and/or confused and disoriented customer can apply. Any residential customer can apply, regardless of income.

-OnTrack Payment Program: Payment plan for customers with limited incomes who are struggling to pay the full cost of their electric service. The program offers a reduced monthly payment and a chance to erase any back debt owed. Eligibility criteria include household income, family size and electric usage.

- Operation HELP: A PPL sponsored fuel fund that helps pay the energy bills of low-income customers. Will help pay for any type of home energy bills. All payments are made directly to energy vendors. Program also covers security deposit waivers. Eligibility criteria includes household income, family size and extenuating circumstances and hardships.

- Rebates: Available for PPL customers who buy new energy, efficient appliances or electrical heating and air conditioning systems.

- Appliance Recycling: Will pick up your old refrigerator or freezer and pay $35 for each. Air conditioning units also taken with refrigerator and freezer pickup.
fields.hours_of_operation:
Hours: Office: Monday through Friday, 8:00am to 5:00pm
Customer Service open 24/7

Provides utility assistance and/or mediation services available for eligible clients experiencing difficulty with utility payments. Intensive follow-up and referral services are provided. Available programs for assistance include:

Penelec Customer Assistance Program allows for a lower monthly bill based on this income.

PPL ON Track Payment Program offers a lower fixed monthly payment for electric bills. PPL will also forgive a portion of payment debt over 18 months as long as OnTrack payments are made on-time each month, at the end of 18 months the overdue balance will be $0. Do not need an overdue bill to qualify.

fields.title: Agency for Community Empowerment of NEPA (ACE)
fields.description:
Addresses Weatherization, furnace, and other energy conservation services to disadvantaged individuals meeting 150% of the federal poverty guidelines.
Weatherization Measures Include:
â¢Air Sealing (Caulking, Weather Stripping, Door Sweeps)
â¢Attic Insulation and Venting
â¢Sidewall Insulation
â¢Window Repairs
â¢Energy Education

Furnace Measures Include:
â¢Furnace Repair
â¢Furnace Cleaning & Tune-up

Home Energy Auditor will evaluate where energy loss is most prevalent and:
.Determine prioritization of allowable measures covered by the Department of Energy.
.Conduct energy education- every-day energy saving practices that will help you lower your heating/cooling costs.
.Provide contact information for any questions or concerns regarding Weatherization.
fields.hours_of_operation: Hours: Mon - Fri, 8:30 am - 4 pm
fields.address: 123 Wyoming Avenue 3rd Floor, Suite 311 Scranton, PA 18503

fields.title: ESCALON PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH
fields.description:
Provides a bag of food to low income individuals and families residing in Escalon, Farmington and Collegeville.Food programs include Weekly Emergency Supplemental Food, Bi-Monthly Senior Brown Bag, Monthly Federal Commodities Program and Second Harvest Mobile Farmer's Market.C.A.R.E. program is administer by Escalon Ministerial Association (EMA), a community based volunteer organization. To volunteer, contact the interim CARE Director.

Eligibility: Must reside in Escalon, Farmington or Collegeville. *Weekly Emergency Supplemental Food: Household income must meet Federal Poverty Level*Senior Brown Bag: Must be over 60 years of age with fixed income *Federal Commodities Program: Household self-certify that meets Federal Guidelines

Requirements: Call for information
fields.hours_of_operation: *Weekly Emergency Supplemental Food hours: Every Wednesay 9:30am-11am except for the week of the Government Commodities.*Senior Brown Bag hours: 2nd and 4th Tuesday of every month 8am-11am*Federal Commodities Program hours: 3rd Thursday of every month 8am-11am*Second Harvest Mobile Farmer's Market: 2nd Tuesday of every month 9:30am-10:30am

fields.title: SECOND HARVEST OF THE GRATER VALLEY (SHGV)
fields.description:
Offers opportunity for low-income seniors to participate in the Senior Brown Bag Program and receive market-sized bags of groceries twice a month for the year to supplement their food supply. There are twenty-six (26) distribution sites county wide.

Eligibility: Participating seniors must meet all criteria: *60 years of age or older*Reside in San Joaquin County*Limited income as follows: Individual monthly income $2,542 or less; Joint monthly income $2,904 or less

Requirements: ID, verification of income, and proof of address

fields.title: CITY OF LATHROP
fields.description:
Provides various creational activities, health and wellness programs, seminars, and resources to senior community.Programs and Services include: Program and Events such as Card Games, Bingo, Shuffleboard, Pool, Karaoke, Potluck, Country Breakfast, Bunco, Ice Cream Social and Guest Speaker Series. Senior Lunch Program (Congregate Meals) - Provides hot lunch meals to seniors. Call 24hr in advance for reservation. Senior Brown Bag Distribution and Commodities Distribution program - Provides prepacked bags of food to low income families and seniors. Senior Legal Services - Provides legal services for seniors and their caregiver. Program is provided by the Council for the Spanish Speaking (El Concilio).

Eligibility: Seniors 50 years of age or olderSenior Lunch Program (Congregate Meals): Must be 50 years of age or olderSenior Brown Bag Distribution: Must be 60 years of age or older and meet income guidelineFood Commodities Distribution and Mobile Farmers Market: Must meet income guidelineSenior Legal Services: Must be 60 years of age or older

Requirements: ID and verification of income

fields.title: REDWOOD ACRES
fields.description:
About
Lost Foods is a local non-profit organization(501c3), dedicated to restoring native plant diversity and abundance and reintroducing native foods to create a sustainable society. Lost Foods created and maintains the Lost Foods Native Plant Nursery and three Native Plant Sanctuaries and promotes and demonstrates the uses of native plants for food, medicine and wildlife habitat.
History
Lost Foods created the Lost Foods Native Plant Nursery at the Redwood Acres Fairgrounds in 2012, to provide a resource of diverse native plants for sale and donation for the public, government agencies, and land restoration projects. Adjacent to the native plant nursery is Lost Foods largest and most diverse Native Plant Sanctuary, also started in 2012. The Lost Foods Native Plant Sanctuary displays and preserves hundreds of native plant species and serves as a living seed bank of diverse native plants. The sanctuary also serves as an educational center for Lost Foods educational activities which include tours and lectures on the many benefits and importance of growing and using native plants for food, medicine and wildlife habitat.
Lost Foods also created and maintains two other Native Plant Sanctuaries; the Old Town Native Plant Garden, was started in 2009 and is located on the corner of 2ndand H Streets in Old Town Eureka. The second Native Plant Sanctuary was created in 2011 and is located at the Ryan House and Garden on the 1000 block of E and F Streets in Eureka.
fields.hours_of_operation: Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays form Noon-6pm or Sunset.

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES (CDSS)
fields.description:
Provides additional food benefits to make up for free or reduced-price meals usually serviced at child care or school that children may have missed because of the pandemic. Benefits do not replace the child nutrition meals, CalFresh, or WIC programs. P-EBT cards can be used the same way at the EBT cards.P-EBT 2.0Families can get up to $123 for each eligible child who lives in a county where at least one school is offering distance learning. And $68 for each eligible child who lives in a county where at least one school is offering hybrid learning. If all schools in the county open for in-person learning, young children living in that county are not eligible for P-EBT.A card will be mailed out to each child approved begining July 2021 through November 2021. Do not through away card as it will be reloaded with additional benefits.

Eligibility: Children whose school was closed due to COVID-19 and receive CalFresh, Medi-Cal or Foster Care benefits and/or are eligible for free or reduced-price school meals.Pandemic EBT 2.0 (P-EBT 2.0):. Young children are eligible for P-EBT 2.0 if between October 1, 2020, and May 31, 2021, they were:-Age 0-6 years old; and-Part of a household getting CalFresh food benefits; and-Living in a county where at least one school facility was closed or limiting in-person instruction..School aged children are eligible for P-EBT 2.0 if they were:-Enrolled at a school for school year 2020-21 that participated in the federal School Breakfast Program or National School Lunch Program; and-Eligible to get free or reduced-price meals for school year 2020-21; and-Assumed to have attended school via all distance learning or a hybrid learning at least some days of the week during school year 2020-21.

Requirements: Check online at www.cdss.ca.gov/pandemic-ebt
fields.hours_of_operation: Website available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a yearCA P-EBT Helpline available Monday-Friday 6am-8pm

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES (CDSS)
fields.description:
Welfare fraud is reported in a variety of ways depending upon the State in which the person(s) lives and thereby where he or she commits the fraud. To report fraud, find the state in which the suspect of committed crime lives. Use the reporting contact information from the website to file the report consistent with the method(s) available in that State. Keep in mind the following when reporting fraud: Anonymously reporting suspected fraud may or may not be permitted by the appropriate officials. If caller wishes to remain anonymous, ask about the policy on anonymous reports before providing any information. Be aware that fraud is normally a criminal offense. Once reported, it is most likely that caller will not be contacted again or 'updated on the progress' of any criminal investigation; it is strictly prohibited in criminal investigations. Have as much information as possible when making the report to include why caller believes or knows the individual receives public assistance and why you believe the individual has committed fraud. The more information available to officials, the more likely investigations will be initiated. Baseless reports filed simply for retribution or spite can result in the individual knowingly making the baseless report vulnerable to criminal charges.

Eligibility: Welfare fraud related issues only

Requirements: Provide as much documentation as possible.
fields.hours_of_operation: 24 hours a day/7 days a week

Applications available on-line, at local career centers, or apply by phone.

Eligibility: California resident who has received enough wages during the base period to establish a claim, is totally or partially unemployed, unemployed through no fault of his/her own, be physically able to work, be available for work which means to be ready and willing to immediately accept work, be actively looking for work, meet eligibility requirements each week benefits are claimed and be approved for training before training benefits can be paid.

Requirements: Social security number; last employer's name, address, telephone number, and last date worked, the specific reason you are no longer working; your citizenship status, and if applicable, your alien registration number, driver's license number or State ID number

fields.title: U.S. CENSUS BUREAU
fields.description:
Collects and provides critical data to lawmakers, business owners, schools, hospitals and many others. The data helps determine congressional representation, inform hundreds of billions in federal funding every year, and provide data that will impact communities for the next decade.The following data is collected in the identified timelines: Population & Housing Census - every 10 years Economic Census - every 5 years Census of Governments - every 5 years American Community Survey - annually Economic Indicators - each indicator is released on a specific schedule, see the Economic Indicator Calendar on the websiteThe Census counts every person living in the 50 states, District of Columbia, and five United States Terriotries. fields.title: FEDERAL EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY (FEMA)
fields.description:
Provides disaster survivors with information, support, services, and a way to access and apply for disaster assistance.

Assistance from the FEMA Individuals and Households Program may include:
Funds for temporary housing, such as rental assistance or reimbursement for hotel costs.
A temporary housing unit when there is a lack of available housing resources to rent.
Funds to support the repair or replacement of owner-occupied homes.
Funds for other uninsured or under-insured disaster-caused expenses and serious needs.
Funds for hazard mitigation assistance to help eligible homeowners repair or rebuild stronger, more durable homes.
Affected individuals can apply for assistance online at DisasterAssistance.gov. Survivors can also use the website to search and apply for disaster assistance from other federal agencies, like loans from the Small Business Association.

Eligibility: Individuals whose insurance, or other forms of disaster assistance services, were not sufficient to cover the expenses and serious needs directly caused by a declared disaster. Must be able to provide proof of citizenship status, identity, and ownership/occupancy.

Requirements: Photos of damaged home and belongings, list of damaged or lost items, insurance determination letter (if you have insurance, you must file a claim), proof of occupancy, and proof of ID.
fields.hours_of_operation: Region IX telephone hours:Seven days a week, 24-hours;Disaster Assistance Helpline:4 am - 10 pm PST

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF FAIR EMPLOYMENT AND HOUSING
fields.description:
Enforces California's civil rights laws. Investigates complaints, mediates disputes, and enforces the law regarding discrimination in:
Employment
Housing
Criminal History in Employment
Business Establishments
State Contractors and Government-Funded Programs
Access for People with Disabilities
and protects the public from hate violence and human trafficking:
Hate Violence
Human Trafficking
File a complaint here. Options for resolution include Dispute Resolution or prosecution after an investigation is made.

Resources for Employers, posters, brochures, fact sheets, and additional information is available on the website.

Anyone needing an accommodation to access department services and information can contact the ADA Coordinator.

 

Eligibility: If you feel you were a victim of discrimination within the state of California.

For employment cases, a complaint must be filed within three years of the date you were harmed.

In most other cases, you must file a complaint within one year of the date you were harmed.

Requirements: Copies of any documents that support your complaint.

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS
fields.description:
Offers long-term care to California veterans who are aged or disabled and, under certain circumstances, to spouses and domestic partners of veterans. These services are provided at eight Veterans Homes throughout the state.

Types of care offered:
Independent Living
Intermediate Nursing Care
Memory Care
Residential Care
Skilled Nursing Care
CalVet also strives to be the hub of veteran resources to provide referrals and collaboration for veteran healthcare.

 

Eligibility: California veterans who are aged or disabled and, under certain circumstances, to spouses and domestic partners of veterans.

QUALIFICATIONS FOR ADMISSION:
1. You are at least age 55 and above. Age requirement is waived for disabled or homeless veterans needing long-term care.

2. You served in the U.S. Armed Forces and you were discharged or
released from active duty under conditions other than dishonorable and
are eligible for health care benefits, hospitalization or domiciliary care in
a veterans' facility in accordance with the rules and regulations of the
U.S. Department of veterans Affairs.

3. You meet the qualifications for a non-veteran spouse or domestic
partner.

4. You are a California resident.

5. You are able to live with and get along with other people in a
structured communal environment.

6. As a condition of entering and to continue to reside in a Veterans
Home, the applicant / member shall:
(a) Obtain and maintain Medicare A, B, and D enrollment, if eligible.
(b) Obtain and maintain Medi-Cal enrollment, if eligible.
(c) If not eligible for Medicare and Medi-Cal, the applicant / member must
obtain and maintain other basic medical insurance policy/policies as
required by Military and Veterans Code 1033(c).
(d) Obtain and maintain United States Department of Veterans Affairs
health care program enrollment, if eligible.

Requirements: Documents To Include With Application:1. IDENTIFICATIONa. Form DD-214: Certificate of Active Duty Dischargeb. Birth Certificatec. DMV Driver's License / Identification Cardd. Social Security Carde. Proof of California Residency (see section A-1)2. INCOME (provide additional information as appropriate)a. Bank Statements (most recent)b. Tax Returns, State and Federal (Latest)c. IRS Forms, W-2 or 1099 (Latest)3. MEDICAL INSURANCE - Copy of front and back of a valid carda. Medi-Cal Cardb. Medicare Cardc. VA Medical Cardd. Dental or Other Insurance Card4. LEGAL / OFFICIAL PAPERSa. Advanced Directives, POLSTb. Power of Attorney and/or DPOAc. Marriage Certificate (if currently married)d. Court Ordered Monthly Payments (spousal/childsupport)e. Final Divorce Decree (if applicable)f. Life Insurance Policyg. Pre-Arranged Burial Planh. Will or TrustI. Criminal Background: Court Documents
fields.hours_of_operation: Monday through Friday 8 am - 5 pm

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS AFFAIRS
fields.description:
Offers long-term care to California veterans who are aged or disabled and, under certain circumstances, to spouses and domestic partners of veterans. These services are provided at eight Veterans Homes throughout the state.

CalVet also strives to be the hub of veteran resources to provide referrals and collaboration for veteran healthcare.

 

Eligibility: California veterans who are aged or disabled and, under certain circumstances, to spouses and domestic partners of veterans.

QUALIFICATIONS FOR ADMISSION:
1. You are at least age 55, or disabled, or homeless.
2. You served in the U.S. Armed Forces and you were discharged or
released from active duty under conditions other than dishonorable and
are eligible for health care benefits, hospitalization or domiciliary care in
a veterans' facility in accordance with the rules and regulations of the
U.S. Department of veterans Affairs.
3. You meet the qualifications for a non-veteran spouse or domestic
partner.
4. You are a California resident.
5. You are able to live with and get along with other people in a
structured communal environment.
6. As a condition of entering and to continue to reside in a Veterans
Home, the applicant / member shall:
(a) Obtain and maintain Medicare A, B, and D enrollment, if eligible.
(b) Obtain and maintain Medi-Cal enrollment, if eligible.
(c) If not eligible for Medicare and Medi-Cal, the applicant / member must
obtain and maintain other basic medical insurance policy/policies as
required by Military and Veterans Code 1033(c).
(d) Obtain and maintain United States Department of Veterans Affairs
health care program enrollment, if eligible.

fields.description:

Payment is made directly to the mortgage lender. Maximum Mortgage Relief $80,000 and maximum Property Tax Relief $20,000.Program is funded by the American Rescue Plan Acts's Homeowner Assistance Fund.Apply online at camortgagerelief.org

Eligibility: Must meet criteria:-Own a single-family home, condo, or permanently affixed manufactured home and currently occupy the property-Faced a pandemic-related financial hardship after January 21, 2020-Household income at or below 100% of county Area Median Income-Missed 2 or more mortgage payments before June 30, 2022 and currently past due-Missed 1 or more property tax payments before May 31, 2022 and currently past due-Must owe $80,000 or less to mortgage lender at the time of application submission-Mortgage lender must be participating in the California Mortgage Relief Program

Requirements: Recent Mortgage Statement; Recent Bank Statements; Recent Utility Bill; Recent Income documentation (i.e. paystubs, tax returns, or unemployment document)Depending on your specific circumstance, other documents may be required.

Other items include blind mobility aids, standing aids, hearing aids, assistive listening devices, alerting devices, signaling aids, computer aids, accessible software, cognitive learning aids, adapted toys, adapted exercise equipment, hospital beds, medical equipment, glasses, closed caption decoders, vehicle adaptation services, and transfer devices such as lifts.

Borrow devices to try for 30 days
Find used devices for free or low cost
Sell used devices

Financial loan program for Ability Tools

fields.title: CALIFORNIA STATE OFFICE OF THE CONTROLLER
fields.description:
The State Controller's Property Tax Postponement Program returned in 2016 after being suspended by the Legislature in 2009. The program allows homeowners who are seniors, are blind, or have a disability to defer current-year property taxes on their principal residence if they meet certain criteria including 40 percent equity in the home and an annual household income of $35,500 or less.
Applications for 2017-18 are now available.  The State Controller's team will begin processing completed applications October 1, 2017 in the order they are received.  Please call (800) 952-5661 or email postponement@sco.ca.gov to join our mailing list.
Filing period extended for homeowners affected by fires in Butte, Lake, Mendocino, Napa, Nevada, Orange, Solano, Sonoma, and Yuba counties.  For information, please refer to the flyer in English  or en español .

Eligibility: Vary according to service

fields.title: CALIFORNIA DEPARTMENT OF HOUSING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT
fields.description:
Helps California homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments. Help is open to all eligible Californians who are currently experiencing pandemic-related hardships and have fallen behind on their housing payments. Program is free and funds do not need to be repaid. Homeowners must meet income requirements to be eligible for financial assistance.Visit www.camortgagerelief.org to use 'Income Requirements' calculator to see if you are eligible. If household income is at or below the amount listed, you may be eligible for assistance. The California Mortgage Relief Program is part of the state's Housing is Key initiative.If you need assistance with your application or have questions about your eligibility, please contact your mortgage servicer or a HUD-certified housing counselor at 1-800-569-4287

Description: Helps California homeowners who have fallen behind on their mortgage payments. Help is open to all eligible Californians who are currently experiencing pandemic-related hardships and have fallen behind on their housing payments. Program is free and funds do not need to be repaid. Homeowners must meet income requirements to be eligible for financial assistance.Visit www.camortgagerelief.org to use 'Income Requirements' calculator to see if you are eligible. If household income is at or below the amount listed, you may be eligible for assistance. The California Mortgage Relief Program is part of the state's Housing is Key initiative.If you need assistance with your application or have questions about your eligibility, please contact your mortgage servicer or a HUD-certified housing counselor at 1-800-569-4287

Eligibility: - Household income of all household members over the age of 18 is at or below 100% of the Area Median Income. AMI Calculator- Homeowner must be at least two payments past due by December 27, 2021- Homeowner must currently own and occupy the property in California as their primary residence.- Homeowner may only own and occupy one property.- Homeowner must attest that they experienced a Qualified Financial Hardship after January 21, 2020. The attestation must describe the nature of the financial hardship.- The original, unpaid principal balance of the homeowner's primary mortgage loan, at the time of origination, cannot be greater than the conforming loan limit (as determined under the provisions of the Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008) in effect at time of origination. To find data on conforming loan limits, visit website.- Homeowners cannot have cash or assets on hand (excluding savings in a retirement account) that is equal to or greater than the relief funds needed + $20,000. (For example, homeowners needing $30,000 to get caught up on their mortgage will be ineligible if they have $50,000 or more in assets).

Requirements: Mortgage Statements, Bank Statements, Utility Bill, Income documentation (i.e. paystubs, tax returns, or unemployment document) Depending on their unique circumstances, some applicants will have to provide different kinds of information as well.Proof of loss of income due to COVID-19, which may include the following items.-A letter of termination from your job-Most recent pay stub with employer's information-Evidence that you have applied for unemployment benefits-Evidence that your unemployment benefits have expired, including unemployment benefits provided through the CARES Act-For those self-employed: tax records, income statements, or other evidence showing loss of income-Other items will be consideredAND one item from each of the following areas:-Verification of identity for all household members-Verification of income for all household members over age of 18-Verification of mortgage payment owed

fields.description:
Provides long-term care to resident Veterans who are age 55 and up, or have a disability (of any age), or are homeless (of any age). Under certain circumstances, serves spouses and domestic partners of Veterans. There are eight CalVet Homes throughout California, including one in Redding. These homes are a system of live-in, residential care facilities. They offer a homelike, small community environment. fields.title: City of Dallas, Office of Community Care
fields.description:
ocial Services
​Social Services & Support Program

The Social Services & Support Program provides emergency assistance to individuals and families who have experienced a temporary financial crisis. Financial services are based on the availability of funds. For assistance, you must either call to schedule an appointment with a caseworker or submit an application to be seen. No walk-ins are allowed.

The Social Services program assists clients with:

Utility Bill Assistance (Electric, Water, Gas)
Rental Assistance
Housing Opportunities for Persons with AIDS (HOPWA)
Emergency Shelter Grants (ESG)
Appointments
If you are interested in Rental or Utilities Assistance through the City of Dallas Office of Community Care, Social Services program, you may call our appointment line to speak with a  caseworker, Monday - Friday - 9am- 2pm. The City of Dallas Social Services program  is not able to assist  people who live outside of City of Dallas’ city limits with Rental Assistance.

West Dallas Multipurpose Center: 214-670-6530

Martin Luther King, Jr. Community Center:  214-670-8416

Documents Needed
U.S. Government issued ID or secondary identification
Social Security Cards for all household members
Lease agreement or proof of homeownership
Proof of household income for the past 30 days
Utility bill
Eviction notice or mortgage delinquency notice
Receipts for bills/expenses paid in the last 30 days
Note: Additional information may be required.

Financial Assistance is based on eligibility and fund availability.

Bilingual staff available.
fields.hours_of_operation: Monday - Friday - 9am- 2pm
fields.address: 2922 Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd., Bldg. A Dallas, TX 75215

fields.title: Lake County Department of Human Services
fields.description: SNAP provides :  - Supplemental assistance to help low-income individuals, seniors and families purchase food. Food benefits are based on household composition,     income and resources of all household members.      - Individuals and Families must be at or below 130% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Individuals and families must meet GROSS income     requirements.    -  Seniors and Disabled must be at or below 165% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Seniors and disabled have to meet NET Income requirements.    - Benefits are issued through the Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) System by using the QUEST card, which is similar to a debit card.

fields.title: University of Colorado Addiction Research and Treatment Services
fields.description:
Provides both residential substance use disorder treatment. Treatment services are individualized with stays up to 90 days. Treatment is trauma informed and gender responsive and are designed to support parenting mothers.

Services include:

  • Individual and group counseling
  • Family counseling
  • Mental health and psychiatric care
  • Medication management
  • Doula services for pregnant women
  • Parenting groups
  • Bonding and attachment
  • Drug and alcohol testing
  • Relapse prevention
  • Medication Assisted Treatment
  • Case management
  • Vocational skills and employment search
  • Life skills training and coping skills
  • Transitional living
  • Coordination of outpatient services/continuing care.

fields.title: Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA)
fields.description:
This is an appointment-only traditional site open on Tuesday's, 2 p.m. - 6 p.m. between February 7th, 2023 - March 28, 2023. Provides free, onsite tax preparation for low income individuals and families by volunteer IRS-certified tax preparers. Services provided may include:

  • Federal and state e-filing is available
  • Colorado Property Tax/Rent/Heat Rebate
  • Schedule A (no Schedule B) for itemized deductions
  • Schedule C for simple, business income like Lyft/Uber, Postmates, etc.
  • EITC (Earned Income Tax Credit) & Child Tax Credits
  • Forms 1099R, RRB1099, SSA 1099
  • Credits: Child & Dependent Care, Energy, and Education
  • Prior year tax returns

fields.title: Denver Human Services
fields.description:
Provides virtual and curbside pickup services to individuals and families in emergent need. Emergency Services Include:

  • Diapers, pullups, and wipes for infants and adults
  • Hygiene items
  • Pet Food (Cat & Dog Food)
  • Vital document fee waivers for basic Colorado state identification cards (i.e., no Drivers' Licenses) and Colorado Birth & Death certificates (No out of state support)
  • Emergency food access, as available.

The team also provides community partner referral support, which include:

  • Dress 4 Success (1 temp, 1 interview, & 1 employment suiting per year)
  • Precious Child
  • New Eyes for the Needy, which is prescription frame support for children & adults (Current prescription -within 24 months)
  • pupillary distance

Services include one-on-one resource navigation, emergent needs support, and a partner handoff to more sustainable long term resources.

fields.title: Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA)
fields.description:
This is an appointment-only traditional site open on Monday, 3 p.m - 6 p.m. between February 6th, 2023 - March 27th where an appointment must be made. Provides free, onsite tax preparation for low income individuals and families by volunteer IRS-certified tax preparers. Services provided may include:

  • Federal and state e-filing is available
  • Colorado Property Tax/Rent/Heat Rebate
  • Schedule A (no Schedule B) for itemized deductions
  • Schedule C for simple, business income like Lyft/Uber, Postmates, etc.
  • EITC (Earned Income Tax Credit) & Child Tax Credits
  • Forms 1099R, RRB1099, SSA 1099
  • Credits: Child & Dependent Care, Energy, and Education
  • Prior year tax returns
