fields.title: Housing and Urban Development Office of Public Housing
fields.description:
Directs customers to the appropriate HUD office to address their inquiry.

The primary programs administered by HUD include:

· Mortgage and loan insurance through the Federal Housing Administration

· Community Development Block Grants (CDBG) to help communities with economic development, job opportunities and housing rehabilitation;

· HOME Investment Partnership Act block grants to develop and support affordable housing for low-income residents;

· Rental assistance in the form of Section 8 contracts or housing vouchers for low-income households;

· Public or subsidized housing for low-income individuals and families;

· Homeless assistance provided through local communities, faith-based organizations and other nonprofit agencies;

· Fair housing public education and enforcement.

fields.title: City of Denver
fields.description:
Offers down payment assistance to moderate-income individuals and families who are eligible. This assistance is in the form of an interest-free, 3-year forgivable second mortgage that is up to a percentage of the mortgage loan amount. There are no scheduled payments, and assistance is forgiven if an individual stays in the home for 3 years.

The metroDPA Social Equity Program offers down payment assistance to residents or descendants of individuals who lived in a Denver neighborhood that was redlined between 1938 - 2000. Depending on one's income, eligible individuals may receive $15,000 or $25,000 in assistance.

fields.title: Colorado Housing and Finance Authority
fields.description: Offers home mortgage programs for low- to moderate-income homebuyers with fixed-rate financing, including home purchase and down payment and/or closing cost assistance grant and second mortgage loan. In addition, sponsors free homebuyer education in English and Spanish across the state to help prepare people for homeownership.

fields.title: Volunteer Income Tax Assistance (VITA)
fields.description:
This is an appointment-only traditional site open on Thursday, 2 p.m. - 6 p.m. between February 9th, 2023 - March 30, 2023. Provides free, onsite tax preparation for low income individuals and families by volunteer IRS-certified tax preparers. Services provided may include:

  • Federal and state e-filing is available
  • Colorado Property Tax/Rent/Heat Rebate
  • Schedule A (no Schedule B) for itemized deductions
  • Schedule C for simple, business income like Lyft/Uber, Postmates, etc.
  • EITC (Earned Income Tax Credit) & Child Tax Credits
  • Forms 1099R, RRB1099, SSA 1099
  • Credits: Child & Dependent Care, Energy, and Education
  • Prior year tax returns

  • Education

  • Recreation
  • STAR (Starting Transition and Recovery):

  • Rowan Gardens:

  • Rocky Mountain Youth Housing:

Supportive housing options for youth are also available in scattered site apartments throughout the community.

fields.description: Housing and Benefits Application Assistance (Glenwood Springs Office) - Center for Independence provides:  Housing location assistance Nursing home transition Case management Benefit advocacy and application assistance.  Housing Services:  - Assist the consumer in finding possible housing leads - Assist the consumer in completing paperwork or applications if needed due to the consumer's disability - Advocate on behalf of the consumer in an effort to resolve landlord/tenant issues.  - Assist the consumer in understanding their rights/responsibilities as a tenant - Assist a consumer in finding possible housing options when being discharged from a hospital - Assist consumers in finding possible housing options and supports when an individual wishes to move from a nursing home back to the    community- - Work with a consumer to help prevent the possibility of a nursing home placement - Assist a consumer in finding possible funding for durable medical or other equipment which would help them to remain independent in their    chosen housing environment - Assisting the consumer in finding vendors who can do home modifications - Answer questions about the ADA, Fair Housing, Service Animals, Therapy Animals and Companion Animals. fields.title: Gunnison County Health and Human Services
fields.description: SNAP provides:  - Supplemental assistance to help low-income individuals, seniors and families purchase food. -  Food benefits are based on household composition, income and resources of all household members.      - Individuals and Families must be at or below 130% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Individuals and families must meet GROSS income requirements. - Seniors and Disabled must be at or below 165% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). - Seniors and disabled have to meet NET Income requirements. - Benefits are issued through the Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) System by using the QUEST card, which is similar to a debit card.

fields.description: Providing a network of health services from in home and community based programs to transitional and long-term care. fields.title: The Dolphin House Child Advocacy Center
fields.description: The Dolphin House provides child abuse victims with a safe, non-threatening place to share their experience and trauma following a necessary investigation.  Services are accessed through referrals from law enforcement or child welfare.   Dolphin House may also provide:   - Medical and mental health services referrals   - Ongoing support for children and their supportive families   - Help obtaining family stability and healing   - Must call to take a tour of the facilities first.  - Must call before to protect the confidentiality of clients who might be present at the moment at the facility. - If you are wanting to report suspected or known child abuse, call the Child Abuse Hotline at 844-CO-4-KIDS (844-264-5437).

fields.title: Center for Independence, Western Slope
fields.description: Provides housing location assistance, nursing home transition, case management, benefit advocacy and application assistance.    Housing Services:   - Assist the consumer in finding possible housing leads   - Assist the consumer in completing paperwork or applications if needed due to the consumer's disability   - Advocate on behalf of the consumer in an effort to resolve landlord/tenant issues. Assist the consumer in understanding their rights/responsibilities as a tenant   - Assist a consumer in finding possible housing options when being discharged from a hospital   - Assist consumers in finding possible housing options and supports when an individual wishes to move from a nursing home back to the community   - Work with a consumer to help prevent the possibility of a nursing home placement   - Assist a consumer in finding possible funding for durable medical or other equipment which would help them to remain independent in their chosen housing environment   - Assisting the consumer in finding vendors who can do home modifications   - Answer questions about the ADA, Fair Housing, Service Animals, Therapy Animals and Companion Animals.    Assistance with applying for any Federal or State Benefit program  Benefit Services:   - Social Security (SSI)   - Social Security Disability Income (SSDI)   - Medicare, Medicaid, Low Income Energy Assistance Program (LEAP)   - Temporary Aid for Needy Families (TANF/Colorado Works)   - Food Stamps (SNAP), Section 8 Housing Vouchers, Aid to the Needy Disabled (AND)
fields.address: 245 South Cascade Avenue Ste B, Montrose, CO 81401

fields.description: Housing Rehabilitation Loan Program  provides" income qualifying homeowners access to low interest-rate loans to repair and maintain their homes.  Some eligible home improvements include:  - Repair and/or replace plumbing, electrical systems and mechanical systems - Remove old shingles and install new roofing materials- Replace old leaking windows with high efficiency duel pane windows - Handicap accessible modifications - Payments, interest rates, and terms of the loans are determined on the basis of how much the client can afford to pay. - The program coordinator secures bids for the projects, coordinates with contractors, helps with inspections, assists with necessary paperwork and    services the loan payments.

fields.title: Delta House
fields.description: Delta House is a 28 bed Medicaid Licensed Assisted Living facility located on Main Street in Delta, Co.  All of our rooms are private with private bath.   Services Provided:  - Medication monitoring and administration - Transportation to local physician appointments - 3 meals daily plus snacks - Housekeeping & Laundry  - Activities  - Protective oversight - Satellite TV service provided to all rooms  - Linens and furniture as needed  - 24 hour on-site staff - Regular health checks - Exercise equipment - Computer learning classes - Spacious dining hall - Resident health monitoring - Personal needs service - Access to staff nurse - Special concierge services - Classes for arts & crafts - Large decks - Aid with medication - Available parking on premises - Pet friendly facility - Friendly staff members - Snack shop - Management of diabetes - Games room with cards and bingo - Hair salon - Gardens - Fall prevention classes

fields.title: Teen Challenge of the Rocky Mountains
fields.description:
Offers a one year residential service providing drug and alcohol addiction recovery services for women and women with children. House of Promise can provide a variety of services for residents, including but not limited to:

  • In-house therapy and counseling
  • Faith-based treatment to overcome addiction and substance abuse
  • Parenting classes
  • Finance classes
  • Life-skills training
  • Transitional housing and job searching assistance during the second year

Women can choose to continue with the treatment program after the first year and take advantage of other services provided only for those who've chosen to stay a 2nd year. Residents participating in the program are expected to follow all rules and policies detailed by the agency.

fields.title: Anciano Tower
fields.description: Anciano Tower offers:  - Anciano Tower is a subsidized housing community for seniors over the age of 62 and those who are mobility/sensory impaired. The term 'subsidized housing” means that the rent is based on income. A resident of the community pays approximately 30% of their income as rent. - The remainder of the rent is paid in the form of a subsidy. If a resident qualifies for a subsidy, the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), a U.S. government agency, will pay the remainder of the rent. - Spacious one-bedroom apartments, as well as a few more accessible apartments for the sensory/mobility impaired. - Currently Anciano Tower has a waiting list. Please call for the approximate waiting time. -  There is a one-year lease, - Anciano Tower welcomes pets. Fish and birds are welcomed without a deposit. Small dogs and cats are welcome with a pet deposit. There is a limit of one animal (cat or dog) per apartment and there are specific size and breed restrictions. - The pet deposit is the same amount as the security deposit with a minimum of $50 and a maximum of $300. Arrangements can be made for this deposit.  Payment arrangements begin with $50 and then a monthly payment of $10 until the deposit is paid in full. -  There is one elevator located in the center of the building, easily accessible by all residents on all floors. Each wing of the building has an elevator. - Anciano Tower has ample parking in the resident parking lot. - There is one laundry center at Anciano Tower, containing four coin-operated washers and four coin-operated dryers with folding and hanging areas and a sink for the convenience of the residents. This center is located on the ground floor. - There is a garbage center on each floor of the building specifically for garbage/recycling purposes. Inside, there is a chute to dispose of trash directly into a dumpster. There are also labeled bins for all recyclables. - Currently the city of Montrose offers a transit service called Just City Run. This service stops at Anciano Tower's door and takes residents along a route throughout the city to a grocery store, departments stores, local restaurants, and other locations. -

fields.title: Housing Resources of Western Colorado
fields.description: Housing Rehabilitation Loan Program  provides" income qualifying homeowners access to low interest-rate loans to repair and maintain their homes.  Some eligible home improvements include:  - Repair and/or replace plumbing, electrical systems and mechanical systems - Remove old shingles and install new roofing materials- Replace old leaking windows with high efficiency duel pane windows - Handicap accessible modifications - Payments, interest rates, and terms of the loans are determined on the basis of how much the client can afford to pay. - The program coordinator secures bids for the projects, coordinates with contractors, helps with inspections, assists with necessary paperwork and    services the loan payments.

fields.title: Housing Resources of Western Colorado
fields.description: HRWC is a HUD approved Housing Counseling Agency.  We provide free, one-on-one counseling and coaching services along with workshops to residents in Western Colorado.  Our counselors work with clients in these areas:  *Rental Counseling *Financial Coaching-budgeting and credit issues *Home buyer Education workshops, Pre-purchase Counseling for those seeking to purchase a home, *Post-purchase Coaching to be a successful homeowner *Foreclosure Prevention *Student Loans

fields.title: Housing Resources of Western Colorado
fields.description: Self-Help Housing Program provides:  - A "sweat equity" program that give income qualified families the means to construct their own home. - Participants in the program must be willing to contribute a minimum of 30 hours/week. Family and friends can contribute up to 15 hours/week which can    count towards the 30 hours needed.

fields.title: Housing Resources of Western Colorado
fields.description: Provides assistance for critical home repairs up to $400 if funding allows to qualified homeowners living in the  city limits of Grand Junction. Must meet income guidelines to be eligible.

fields.title: Housing Resources of Western Colorado
fields.description: Administers the weatherization program that helps to improve the energy efficiency of residential structures throughout Colorado. Applicants must rent or own their home and includes mobile homes.  They must first qualify for the program and then request an energy audit.  Weatherization improvements the may be available depending on the findings of the energy audit:   - Insulation in attics and walls - Furnace replacement- Furnace safety testing - Refrigerator replacement - Sealing air leaks - Compact fluorescent light bulbs (CFL) - Storm windows - Energy conservation information -Hot water heater

fields.title: Homeward Bound of the Grand Valley
fields.description: Veteran's Transitional Housing: -The Phoenix Project provides homeless veterans in Mesa County access to affordable, stable housing and individually tailored case management services in an effort to transition them from homelessness into self-sufficiency. -The program can currently house 8 homeless veterans in an apartment complex .   -Rents are based on 30 and 40% of Area Median Income.

fields.title: Homeward Bound of the Grand Valley
fields.description: Homeward Bound offers coaching and support to guests as they apply for government benefits, attend counseling sessions, seek employment and locate stable housing. Guests work with a case manager to identify barriers to success and create individualized housing and service plans outlining steps to overcome those barriers. They also offer vocational training in culinary arts through the kitchen staff. This offers guests training and experience in food safety, food preparation and daily operational functions in a commercial kitchen setting.

fields.title: Volunteers of America Colorado
fields.description:
Provides Veterans and their families with the following:

  • Case management
  • Temporary financial assistance for security deposits
  • Rent assistance

A case manager works with the veteran and their family to develop a plan toward stable housing.

fields.title: The Joseph Center
fields.description: The Golden Girls project through The Joseph Center provides transitional housing for middle aged the elderly women 50+. While waiting for SSI/SSDI benefits, survivors benefits, securing employment, and securing permanent housing, Golden Girls can be housed free of charge for up to 6 months. Large two-bedroom space with a max of 4 beds. Guests have access to a kitchen, bathroom, shower, television and internet.  Also provides on site case management, health clinic every other Thursday, program navigation and resource assistance.

fields.title: Montrose County Department of Human Services
fields.description: Provides supplemental assistance to help low-income individuals, seniors and families purchase food. Food benefits are based on household composition, income and resources of all household members.  Benefits are issued through the Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) System by using the QUEST card, which is similar to a debit card.

fields.title: Ouray County Department of Social Services
fields.description: Provides supplemental assistance to help low-income individuals, seniors and families purchase food. Food benefits are based on household composition, income and resources of all household members.  Individuals and Families must be at or below 130% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Individuals and families must meet GROSS income requirements.    Seniors and Disabled must be at or below 165% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL). Seniors and disabled have to meet NET Income requirements.  Benefits are issued through the Electronic Benefit Transfer (EBT) System by using the QUEST card, which is similar to a debit card.

fields.title: Valley Food Partnership
fields.description: Nutrition Assistance and Education provides:   - Family-friendly cooking and nutrition education classes   - Farmacy Bucks, an incentive program for the classes to purchase local fruits and vegetables   - Healthy recipe ideas using local fruits and vegetables   - Bonus kitchen items, call for details   - Education on how to purchase health food on a budget - Local Farmacy Rx can also provide families with fruit and vegetable prescriptions that they can take to their local grocery store. - There is no cost for families if they are receiving SNAP (Food Stamps) and/or Medicaid benefits. -  Families must commit to attending 4 or 6 classes and 1 orientation.

fields.title: Center for Independence, Western Slope
fields.description: Housing and Benefits Application Assistance (Montrose Office) - Center for Independence provides:  Housing location assistance Nursing home transition Case management Benefit advocacy and application assistance.  Housing Services:  - Assist the consumer in finding possible housing leads - Assist the consumer in completing paperwork or applications if needed due to the consumer's disability - Advocate on behalf of the consumer in an effort to resolve landlord/tenant issues.  - Assist the consumer in understanding their rights/responsibilities as a tenant - Assist a consumer in finding possible housing options when being discharged from a hospital - Assist consumers in finding possible housing options and supports when an individual wishes to move from a nursing home back to the    community- - Work with a consumer to help prevent the possibility of a nursing home placement - Assist a consumer in finding possible funding for durable medical or other equipment which would help them to remain independent in their    chosen housing environment - Assisting the consumer in finding vendors who can do home modifications - Answer questions about the ADA, Fair Housing, Service Animals, Therapy Animals and Companion Animals.   Assistance with applying for any Federal or State Benefit program  Benefit Services:  - Social Security (SSI) - Social Security Disability Income (SSDI) - Medicare, Medicaid, Low Income Energy Assistance Program (LEAP) - Temporary Aid for Needy Families (TANF/Colorado Works) - Food Stamps (SNAP), Section 8 Housing Vouchers, Aid to the Needy Disabled (AND)  All services for the Montrose are being provided by the Grand Junction office temporarily.

Assist the consumer in understanding their rights/responsibilities as a tenant   - Assist a consumer in finding possible housing options when being discharged from a hospital   - Assist consumers in finding possible housing options and supports when an individual wishes to move from a nursing home back to the community   - Work with a consumer to help prevent the possibility of a nursing home placement   - Assist a consumer in finding possible funding for durable medical or other equipment which would help them to remain independent in their chosen housing environment   - Assisting the consumer in finding vendors who can do home modifications   - Answer questions about the ADA, Fair Housing, Service Animals, Therapy Animals and Companion Animals.    Assistance with applying for any Federal or State Benefit program  Benefit Services:   - Social Security (SSI)   - Social Security Disability Income (SSDI)   - Medicare, Medicaid, Low Income Energy Assistance Program (LEAP)   - Temporary Aid for Needy Families (TANF/Colorado Works)   - Food Stamps (SNAP), Section 8 Housing Vouchers, Aid to the Needy Disabled (AND)

fields.title: The Tree House Center for Youth
fields.description: Youth Prevention Services provides: -  A safe and enriching environment, one that is both programmatic and empowering and that is drug, alcohol and violence free.  - Total programs serving over 1,000 individual youth per year, The Tree House provides a variety of OST (Out of School Time) prevention service opportunities, all of which foster character building, civic engagement, and life skills development. -  These programs serve youth between the ages of 11-22 in Mesa County. - Offers intervention and prevention development opportunities through tailored education, support, advocacy, community involvement, leadership training, and enrichment activities.  - The Tree House programs bolster self-esteem and positive life choices, nurturing the social, emotional and educational growth of the    area’s youth as well as promoting healthy life choices and a positive, productive future.

fields.title: Tri-County Health Network
fields.description: Food Security programs include:  Cooking Matters:   -A hands-on, six week cooking-based nutrition, education program that provides the skills, knowledge and confidence to prepare healthy and affordable meals.     - Nutrition lessons  - Meal preparation education   - Grocery shopping tips   - Food budgeting skills     - Each participant receives a bag of groceries to replicate the meal they’ve created - Class days and times can vary, call for specific information on the next available class.  Snap Food Benefits Program: -Clients can apply for SNAP by contacting local expert navigators in Ouray, Telluride, and Norwood West End:  - Ridgway/Ouray  Cecilia Castro: 970-417-7143   -Norwood/West End Nadia Gonzalez: 970-519-1117  -Telluride Nadia Gonzalez: 970-519-1117  - Delta/Montrose Kimberly Meraz: 970-765-8866   For Spanish-speaking clients: - Telluride Area/Norwood/West End Nadia Gonzalez: 970-519-1117  -Montrose/Delta: Cecilia Castro: 970-417-7143  Food RX : - This program offered in partnership with local medical clinics uses food as medicine to improve patient health outcomes. - Through TCHNetwork’s FoodRx Program, patients with a chronic disease who enroll in the program at Basin Clinic, Uncompahgre Medical Center, and the Telluride Regional Medical Center receive $120 in vouchers over 7 weeks to purchase fresh fruits and vegetables from participating stores.  - The patients also receive coaching from clinic staff on how to stretch their FoodRx dollars and  how to best incorporate fresh fruits and vegetables into their diet.  FoodRx Coordinators at partner clinics in Naturita, Norwood, and Telluride: - Naturita: Cyndi Wargowsky at Basin Clinic 970-865-2665 - Norwood: Sage Carver at Uncompahgre Medical Center 970-327-0624 - Telluride: Ryan O’Donnell. R.N. at Telluride Medical Center 970-728-3848 x122

fields.hours_of_operation: Mon V - V; Tue V - V; Wed V - V; Thu V - V; Fri V - V; Sat V - V; Sun V - V;

fields.title: Conejos County
fields.description:
Services include:

  • Aid to the Blind (AB)
  • Aid to the Needy Disabled (AND)
  • Child/Adult Protection Services (CPS/APS)
  • Children's Health Plan Plus (CHP+)
  • Colorado Child Care Assistance Program (CCCAP)
  • Medicaid
  • Old Age Pension (OAP)
  • Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP)
  • Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF)
  • Senior programs
  • Individuals with disabilities programs
fields.hours_of_operation: Mon O - O; Tue O - O; Wed O - O; Thu O - O; Fri O - O; Sat O - O; Sun O - O; Mon 08:00 AM - 04:30 PM; Fri 08:00 AM - 04:30 PM; Thu 08:00 AM - 04:30 PM; Wed 08:00 AM - 04:30 PM; Tue 08:00 AM - 04:30 PM;

fields.title: Colorado State University Extension
fields.description:
Provides resources information on health and food including:

  • Foodborne illness
  • Food preparation
  • Food preservation
  • Food safety & local foods
  • Food storage
  • High risk & special audiences
  • High altitude preparation
  • Nutrition & health
